The odd index (position 1) is even (parity 0). To make it even, no need to flip. 

So, set y=1 (even operations once), x=0 (no odd operations). 

Then, even indices become even, odd index remains even. So all even. So possible. 

Thus the code's logic works here. 

Another test case where even indices are mixed. Like array [1, 2, 3,4]. 

Even indices 0 and 2: 1 (odd) and 3 (odd) → so even indices are all odd. 

Wait, no, 1 and 3 are both odd → so even indices are same. 

Wait, but if the array was [1,2,2,4], then even indices 0 (1, odd) and 2 (2 even). Then even indices have mixed parities. 

In that case, the code would have ee=1 (position 2 is even) and eo=1 (position 0 is odd). So ee and eo both non-zero → the second condition (else if) would trigger, outputting NO. Which is correct because you can't make them all same. 

Yes, so the code's logic is correct. 

Therefore, the missing code is indeed a%2 ==0.
